21.text: The Bundesrat is a legislative body

23.text:
made up of delegates from
the sixteen State Assemblies.

27.text:
Each state has three to six votes,
depending on their population.

31.text:
The Bundestag, on the other hand,
is made up of elected representatives,

36.text:
plus a number of other representatives,
which I’ll explain later.

40.text:
Together, the Bundestag and Bundesrat
propose legislation,

43.text: which is then debated and voted on.

45.text:
The Constitutional Court ensures that
any legislation

48.text: does not violate the German Basic Law.

51.text:
The executive branch
of the German political system

54.text:
is made up of the Chancellor,
the Cabinet and the President.

57.text:
The Chancellor is elected by the Bundestag,
and is the head of government.

62.text:
The Chancellor then appoints
members of the Cabinet.

65.text:
The President, on the other hand,
is head of state,

68.text:
and is elected by the Bundesversammlung,
the Federal Assembly.

72.text:
This body consists of the entire Bundestag
plus special envoys from the 16 states.

78.text: Its sole purpose is to elect the President.

84.text:
and has great influence over
the general policies of the government.

87.text: The President’s role is mostly ceremonial,

90.text: but he can refuse to sign a bill into law

92.text: if he believes it to be unconstitutional,

94.text:
or if the proper democratic procedure
was not observed.

In each consituency,

126.text:
But the seats they win don’t necessarily

141.text: the total number seats each party has

143.text:

148.text:
The party with the most seats
usually gets to form the government,

151.text: but they need an absolute majority.

154.text:
Since Germany has more than two major
political parties, this almost never happens,

158.text:
and so the biggest party must form a coalition
with one of the smaller parties.

164.text:
In the last elections, in 2009,
the CDU/CSU Union got 239 seats:

170.text: the biggest share, but less than half the total.

174.text: They formed a coalition with the FDP,

176.text:
bringing their share to 332,
an absolute majority.

181.text:
The German political system is
more complicated than this, of course,

185.text: but this is how it works in principle.
